abstract.text: A view controller that presents standard screens for adding and removing people from a CloudKit share record.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: CloudKit Sharing provides real-time collaboration between one or more people using your app. A user takes certain steps to make collaboration possible, from inviting people to participate in the collaboration to setting restrictions on what participants can do. To provide these steps to a user, you must make changes to your app. With
, the changes require minimum effort.
The
view controller class provides screens, presented within your app, for managing the people, permissions, and access rights associated with a
record. The controller, along with a few lines of your own code, facilitates the setup and management of online sharing between users, making it possible for a user to:
Invite people to view or collaborate on a shared record
Set the access rights determining who can access the shared record (only people invited or anyone with the share link)
Set general or individual permissions (read-only or read/write)
Remove access from one or more participants
Stop participating (if the user is a participant)
Stop sharing with all participants (if the user is the owner of the shared record)
The controller provides these different actions to the user based on the user’s role. If the user is the individual sharing the record (where the record is an instance of
representing the data to share), then the user is called the
owner
. A user who has access to the shared record and isn’t the owner is known as a
participant
. There’s no need for you to specify the user’s role. The controller determines the role automatically.

content.text: Inviting participants to a new share

inlineContent.text: The user who owns the data, represented as a

, can invite others to view or collaborate on changes to the data. To invite participants, the owner sends the share link to the other people. To provide this capability in your app, create an instance of
using the
initializer method. You use this initializer method only when the owner isn’t already sharing the record.

After creating the controller, you present it. The controller displays the Invitation screen. Using this screen, the owner can add participants and set restrictions on the shared record. Once done, the owner sends the share link to the participants.
However, before the owner can send the share link, CloudKit must generate the link. This link generation happens when saving a new
record, but when do you save it? You save the share record in the
After the owner’s selections are complete, the controller invokes the preparation handler provided in the initializer call. In the handler, you create a new
instance, initializing it with the
instance that represents the data to share. (This record is called the “root record.”) Next, you save the share and root records using
. Finally, you return the shared record to the controller or return an error if the save failed. See the following code for an example of this in action.

code: let cloudSharingController = UICloudSharingController { [weak self] (controller, completion: @escaping (CKShare?, CKContainer?, Error?) -> Void) in
func share(rootRecord: CKRecord, completion: @escaping (CKShare?, CKContainer?, Error?) -> Void) {

UICloudSharingController *cloudSharingController = [[UICloudSharingController alloc] initWithPreparationHandler:^(UICloudSharingController * _Nonnull controller, void (^ _Nonnull preparationCompletionHandler)(CKShare * _Nullable, CKContainer * _Nullable, NSError * _Nullable)) {
- (void)shareRootRecord:(CKRecord *)rootRecord completion:(void (^)(CKShare * _Nullable share, CKContainer * _Nullable container, NSError * _Nullable error))completion

content.text: Adding and removing participants from an existing share

inlineContent.text: To allow the owner of an existing share to manage the participants, create the
instance using the
initializer method.
After you create the controller, present it to show the People screen. From this screen, the owner can:
Add and remove participants
Change the share’s access options from private to public, or public to private
Change the share’s permissions from read-only to read/write, or vice versa
Stop sharing with all participants
If all participants have left the share, the controller presents the Invitation screen, not the People screen, when
is used to create the controller instance.

content.text: Viewing participants and leaving a share

inlineContent.text: To allow a participant to view the list of participants and remove themselves from a share, create the
instance using the
initializer method.
After you create the controller, present it to show the People screen. From this screen, the participant can:
View the list of participants
Copy the share link to send to others (if the owner has made the share publicly available)
Leave the share
is designed for use in a popover. Therefore, you should always set the
source information before presenting the Cloud sharing controller. Doing this ensures that the
instance is displayed properly across all device types.
Presenting the Cloud sharing controller in an iPad app without setting the popover presentation controller causes a run-time error.
The following code shows an example of setting the
before presenting a Cloud sharing controller.

code: let cloudSharingController = UICloudSharingController { (controller, completion: @escaping (CKShare?, CKContainer?, Error?) -> Void) in
// Save the share and root records.
if ([self recordToShare] == nil || [sender isKindOfClass:[UIBarButtonItem class]] == NO) {

UICloudSharingController *cloudSharingController = [[UICloudSharingController alloc] initWithPreparationHandler:^(UICloudSharingController * _Nonnull controller, void (^ _Nonnull preparationCompletionHandler)(CKShare * _Nullable, CKContainer * _Nullable, NSError * _Nullable)) {
// Save the share and root records

inlineContent.text: By default, the

user interface displays a generic thumbnail image and title to the user. You can, however, change these to app-specific representations of the shared record. You accomplish this by setting the controller’s
property to an object that conforms to the
protocol, making sure to implement the
and
delegate methods.
You can also show or hide the permission and access options presented to the user by setting the
property on the
instance.

abstract.text: An operation that modifies one or more records.
A collection of key-value pairs that store your app’s data.
A specialized record type that manages a collection of shared records.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A view controller that presents standard screens for adding and removing people from a CloudKit share record.
A set of options that determine the permission options available to the user when viewing the Cloud sharing controller screens.
The activity item object that can be used by an activity view controller.
A combination of permission and access options made available to the user when viewing screens presented by the CloudKit sharing controller.
A reference to an object that conforms to the CloudKit sharing controller delegate protocol.
Initializes the CloudKit sharing controller with a preparation handler intending to save a new share record.
Initializes the CloudKit sharing view controller with a CloudKit share record and container to manage participants and restrictions.
A reference to the CloudKit share record used by the CloudKit sharing controller.
The protocol you implement to provide additional information to, and receive notifications from, the CloudKit sharing controller.
Asks the delegate for the thumbnail image data to display on the invitation.
Asks the delegate for the title to display on the invitation screen.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
The nearest popover presentation controller that is managing the current view controller.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
